SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces or answering them in a manner which does not reflect accurately your experiences.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the place and time referred to, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Mist: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Really Think?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing and churchwork
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces or answering incorrectly. If there is not sufficient space to enter the answers, please feel free to give details, or describe the particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

1. Your full name: Truman Thomas Lake
2. Your address: 385 Euclid Avenue, Long Beach (CA) California
3. Date: May 4th, 1954
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Arthur, Ontario, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Thomas Jones Lake, Hotel owner
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): June 1885
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). Three years of age.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To better ourselves.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). Advertising by Can Pac Ky Coy.
Lake, Truman Thomas
233 Euclid Avenue,
Long Beach (3) California. 1963.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Thought it was a wise move.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
    As a family on the Can Pac Ry.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    Train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    At Moosomin, Saskatchewan, then the N.W.T.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
    Father homesteaded west of Moosomin, 7 miles.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    Left Moosomin, to take employment as agent on the Can Pac Ry., at several stations between Brandon and Moose Jaw and finished up at my old home town of Moosomin as CPR agent till pensioned off.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
    Just three years of age.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?  
Thought it was a wise move.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?  
As a family on the Canadian Pacific Railway.

13. What means of transportation did you use?  
Train.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the train, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?  
At Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, then the N.W.T.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?  
Father homesteaded west of Moose Jaw, 7 miles.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.  
Left Moose Jaw, to take employment and homestead at several stations between Moose Jaw and finished up at my old home town of Moose Jaw.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?  
Just three years of age.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Too young when left there.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Marguerite Elizabeth White,
   Married June 6th 1904 at Brandon, Manitoba, Canada.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

34. Did any peoples move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

English settlement around Moosomin were not experienced as farmers when they came from England and gave up farming.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

About 10% few returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1) & (2), (3).

Moosomin, (named after an Indian chief.

Esterhazy (named as Count Esterhazy.)
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

English settlement around Mosonlin was not experienced.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

About 10% have returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Estherbay (named as Count Esternary.)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations. One daughter Muriel and three sons, Lyle, Harold and Meno.

Daughter Muriel, now Mrs. G.F. Size, husband principal Earl Grey, Sask school.

Lyle E. Lake, accountant and builder at Whittier, California.

Harold E. Lake, manager of the Eldorado Mining Company at Fort Radium N.W.T.

Meno T. Lake, head actuary of the head office of the Occidental Insurance Company at Los Angeles, California.

Harold graduated as engineer at Butte, Mont., and Meno graduated at Commerce at the Manitoba University, Winnipeg, both in the year 1940.
